title: Switch Statements (Multiple Choice Menu)

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Checks variable against multiple specific values. Variable must be int, string, char, or other comparable type. Can't use bool or ranges.
Each case is a specific value to match. case 1: checks if variable equals 1. Colon : ends the case. Can have many cases. Values must be constants!
REQUIRED to exit switch after case runs! Without break, code 'falls through' to next case (usually a bug). Always end each case with break.
Runs if NO cases match. Like else in if/else. Optional but recommended! Handles unexpected values. Put at end of switch (convention).

challenge.instructions:
Create a coffee shop ordering system!

1. Display menu:
   1 - Espresso ($3)
   2 - Latte ($4)
   3 - Cappuccino ($4)
   4 - Americano ($3)
   5 - Mocha ($5)

2. Ask user for choice (1-5)
3. Ask for size (S/M/L)
4. Use switch for drink selection
5. Use switch for size pricing:
   - S: base price
   - M: +$1
   - L: +$2
6. Calculate total and display order

Example:
Choice: 2 (Latte)
Size: L
Order: Large Latte
Price: $6 ($4 + $2 for large)
challenge.hint: Use switch (choice) with cases 1-5. Set drink name and base price in each case. Use switch (size) for 'S', 'M', 'L'. Add to price with +=. Don't forget break in each case!
commonStickingPoints: Forgetting break: Each case MUST end with break! Without it, code falls through to next case (usually unwanted). switch (x) { case 1: code; break; } always!
Using variables in case: case must be CONSTANT! case x: where x is variable is ERROR. Must be case 1: or case \"text\": - literal values only.
Range checking: switch can't do ranges! Can't do case > 10:. Must use if for ranges. Switch is for EXACT matches only: case 1:, case 2:, etc.
Missing default: Without default, nothing runs if no match. Always add default to handle unexpected input! Even if just: default: Console.WriteLine(\"Invalid\"); break;
